children.structure_process: 1. Define the Problem → 2. Research → 3. Specify Requirements → 4. Brainstorm Solutions → 5. Choose Best Solution → 6. Develop Prototype → 7. Test and Evaluate → 8. Improve and Redesign → 9. Communicate Results

children.examples: Designing a water filtration system, Building a robotic arm, Developing a bridge structure

children.terminology: 1. Define the Problem → Identify Needs / Clarify Challenge
2. Research → Gather Data / Learn from Existing Solutions
3. Specify Requirements → Set Goals / Define Constraints
4. Brainstorm Solutions → Generate Ideas / Explore Options
5. Choose Best Solution → Decision Making / Feasibility Analysis
6. Develop Prototype → Create Model / Construct Design
7. Test and Evaluate → Assess Functionality / Identify Flaws
8. Improve and Redesign → Refine / Iterate Based on Feedback
9. Communicate Results → Present Findings / Share Process

children.question: What is the core problem we are trying to solve?
Why is this problem important to address?
How can we clearly define the needs of the user or client?
What assumptions are we making at the start?
What boundaries shape this challenge?
How does identifying the problem affect all later steps?
What are the visible and hidden parts of this problem?
What if the problem is framed too narrowly?
How might this stage influence the emotional investment of a team?
Why might a vague problem statement lead to poor solutions?
What role does intention play in defining engineering problems?
How can student teams agree on a shared understanding of the problem?
What kinds of sources or data should we look for?
How does past work influence our direction?
What existing solutions could inform our design?
How can we judge the quality of our research findings?
Why is diverse research important in technical design?
What patterns emerge from our findings?
How does research connect to user needs?
What if the data conflicts or is unclear?
How does deep research affect our confidence or mood in proceeding?
